Forum Games - Mafia?

21
Claudaro
Thursday, August 10th, 2017, 10:01:05 PM

For an example of this in action, see the xkcd forums - http://forums.xkcd.com/viewforum.php?f=53

Basic premise for a standard newbie-ish game is there are two factions, town and mafia, town don't know whose who, and may consist of a few power roles added in to mostly vanilla players. Mafia is significantly smaller, but know who each other are. Game has a day and a night phase. Day phase players make posts and try and figure out whose mafia, and vote to lynch them, thus killing that person. During the night, mafia can talk via PMs, but town can not talk. Mafia get to pick a player to try and kill overnight. The cycle then repeats. There are near limitless variations based on number of factions, power roles, ect, but that is the bare bones of it.

If this is something that would interest you to try, I'd be willing to run a fairly simple game to introduce people to it, but only if there is sufficient interest. Post here with any thoughts, or if interested.

eric
Friday, August 11th, 2017, 4:02:37 PM

I have seen this game on another forum. I strongly encourage anyone who plays to try and remember this: it's not personal. The whole point of the game is that nobody can trust anyone. You will be falsely accused and you will falsely accuse. Good luck!

Claudaro
Friday, August 11th, 2017, 5:19:07 PM

Size can vary, but a good "minimum" would be seven people plus the person running the game. While less is doable, it just isn't as fun IMO.

Claudaro
Saturday, August 19th, 2017, 11:49:23 AM

@flimbo

This is almost as bare bones basic as it can get. Some of the games I've played in or run have been so extremely complex that it's taken many hours of time to process a game phase due to so many actions and their interactions. I find those kind of games most fun personally because they really allow a lot of creativity with roles and powers, and there is a lot of game theory that goes into the setups you create to determine if it's a fair/balanced game for all parties to have a chance to win.
